  • Date and time logged out and returned

  • Name and signature of the current custodian

  • Name and signature of custodian recipient

  • Reason for transfer

controls.control: Transfers of custody between two individuals must be authorized and logged.

testingProcedures.description: Examine evidence that any transfer of checked out media is authorized and logged.

controls.control: Transfer of removable media to and from the SOC must be authorized and logged.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of media that was removed from the HSA to verify that the removal was authorized and logged.

controls.control: Physically destroy any media containing secret or confidential data when it is not possible to delete the data so that it is no longer recoverable.

testingProcedures.description: Examine evidence that media containing secret or confidential media is destroyed in a manner that makes it impossible to recover the data.

controls.control: Security Testing and Monitoring
Vulnerability
Perform quarterly external network vulnerability scans using an Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV) approved by the Payment Card Industry Security Standards Council (PCI SSC).

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of external vulnerability scans and verify that quarterly external vulnerability scans occurred in the most recent 12-month period and were completed by a PCI SSC Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV).

Examine policies and procedures to verify that quarterly external network vulnerability scans using an Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV) approved by the Payment Card Industry Security Standards Council (PCI SSC) are required.

controls.control: Perform internal and external network vulnerability scans at least quarterly and after any significant change in the network (such as new system-component installations, changes in network topology, firewall-rule modifications, product upgrades). Scans after changes may be performed by internal staff.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample (including the most recent significant change in the network) of internal and external network vulnerability scans to verify scans occur at least quarterly and after any significant change in the network.
Examine policies and procedures to verify that internal and external network vulnerability scans are required at least quarterly and after any significant change in the network.

controls.control: Ensure all findings from network vulnerability scans are prioritized and tracked. Corrective action for high-priority vulnerabilities must be started within two working days.

testingProcedures.description: Interview responsible personnel to verify that all findings from network vulnerability scans are prioritized and tracked, and corrective action for high-priority vulnerabilities is started within two working days.

Examine a sample of documentation to verify that findings from network vulnerability scans are prioritized and tracked, and corrective action for high-priority vulnerabilities is started within two working days.

controls.control:
Retain evidence of successful remediation and make this evidence

available during site compliance evaluations upon request.

testingProcedures.description: Interview responsible personnel to verify evidence of successful remediation is retained and available upon request.

controls.control: Penetration
Perform internal and external penetration tests at least once a year and after any significant infrastructure changes.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedures to verify that internal and external penetration tests are performed at least once a year and after any significant infrastructure changes.

controls.control: The internal penetration test must not be performed remotely.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine the most recent internal and external penetration tests to verify that the following requirements, at a minimum, were met:

The internal penetration test was not performed remotely.

controls.control: Penetration tests must be performed on the network layer and include all SOC network components as well as operating systems.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine the most recent internal and external penetration tests to verify that the following requirements, at a minimum, were met:

Penetration tests were performed on the network layer and included all personalization network components as well as operating systems.

controls.control:
Penetration tests must be performed on the application layer and must include:

  • Injection flaws⎯e.g., SQL injection

  • Buffer overflow

  • Insecure cryptographic storage

  • Improper error handling

  • All other discovered network vulnerabilities

testingProcedures.description:
Penetration tests were performed on the application layer and included at least the following:

  • Injection flaws—e.g., SQL injection

  • Buffer overflow

  • Insecure cryptographic storage

  • Improper error handling

  • Insecure communications

  • All other discovered high-risk network vulnerabilities

controls.control: Ensure all findings from penetration tests are prioritized and tracked. Corrective action for high-priority vulnerabilities must be started within two working days.

testingProcedures.description: Interview responsible personnel to verify that all findings from penetration tests are prioritized and tracked; and corrective action for high-priority vulnerabilities is started within two working days.

Examine a sample of documentation to verify that findings from penetration tests are prioritized and tracked; and corrective action for high-priority vulnerabilities is started within two working days.

controls.control: Retain evidence of successful remediation and make this evidence available during site compliance evaluations upon request.

testingProcedures.description: Interview responsible personnel to verify evidence of successful remediation is retained and available upon request.

controls.control: Intrusion-Detection Systems

Use intrusion-detection systems (IDS) for network traffic analysis. IDS may be implemented as part of an intrusion-prevention system (IPS) if an IPS is used. These must be deployed, managed, and maintained across the vendor networks not only for intrusion detection and prevention but also to monitor all SOC network traffic.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedures to verify that intrusion-detection systems are in place to monitor all traffic across the vendor networks, generated by machines within the perimeter, all SOC network traffic.

Examine a sample of system configurations and network diagrams to verify that intrusion-detection systems are in place to monitor all traffic across the vendor networks, generated by machines within the perimeter, all SOC network traffic.

controls.control: Ensure the IDS alerts personnel to suspicious activity in real time.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of records to verify the IDS alerts personnel to suspicious activity in real time.
Interview responsible personnel to confirm intrusion-detection and/or intrusion-prevention techniques alert personnel of suspected compromises in real time.

controls.control: Ensure the IDS monitors all traffic at the SOC network perimeter as well as at critical points inside the SOC network.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine system configurations and network diagrams to verify that intrusion-detection systems are in place to monitor all traffic:

  • At the perimeter of the SOC network

  • At critical points inside the SOC network

controls.control: Change Management

Ensure that change-control procedures address, at a minimum:

  • That requests for changes are submitted by authorized users.

  • Identification of components that will be changed.

  • Documentation of impact and back-out procedures.

  • Attestation of successful testing, when required.

  • Maintenance of an audit trail of all change requests.

  • Record of whether or not change was successful.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine change-control policies and procedures to verify the following are defined:

  • Ensuring that requests for changes are submitted by authorized users

  • Identification of components that will be changed

  • Documentation of impact and back-out procedures

  • Attestation of successful testing, when required

  • Maintenance of an audit trail of all change requests

  • Record of whether or not the change was successful

controls.control: Ensure that network and system changes follow a documented change-management process and the process is validated at least every 12 months.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation and supporting evidence to verify that the change-management process is validated at least every 12 months.
Examine a sample of changes to network and system components to verify changes follow the documented change-management process.

controls.control:
Ensure all changes are approved by the CISO or authorized

individual prior to deployment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of changes to network and system components to verify changes were approved by the CISO or authorized individual before deployment.

controls.control: Ensure that the change-management process includes procedures for emergency changes.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample (if applicable) of emergency changes to verify they followed procedures.
Interview personnel and review documentation to verify that the change-management process includes procedures for emergency changes.

controls.control: Implement version identification and control for all software and documentation.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify the organization’s change-management policies and procedures include requirements for version control and identification.

controls.control: Ensure that the version identification is updated when a change is released or published.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that version identification is updated when a change is released or published.

controls.control: Implement a controlled process for the transfer of a system from test mode to live mode, and from live mode to test mode.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify the existence of a controlled process for the transfer of a system from test mode to live mode, and from live mode to test mode.

controls.control: Ensure that both development and production staff must sign off on the transfer of a system from test to live, and from live to test. This sign-off must be witnessed under dual control.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine a sample of change-management documentation for system transfers from test to live and from live to test to verify that:

  • Both development and production staff sign off on the transfer of a system from test to live, and from live to test; and

  • This sign-off must be witnessed under dual control.

controls.control: Configuration and Patch Management
Implement a documented procedure to determine whether applicable patches and updates have become available.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify that they include determination of whether applicable patches and updates have become available.

controls.control: Make certain a process is implemented to identify and evaluate newly discovered security vulnerabilities and security patches from software vendors.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that processes are defined to identify new security vulnerabilities and obtain security patches from appropriate software vendors.

controls.control: Ensure that secure configuration standards are established for all system components.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that secure configuration standards are established for all system components.

controls.control: Ensure that the configuration standards include system hardening by removing all unnecessary functionality, such as scripts, drivers, features, subsystems, file systems, and unnecessary web servers.

testingProcedures.description: Examine configuration standards and verify there are requirements to remove all unnecessary functionality, such as scripts, drivers, features, subsystems, file systems, and unnecessary web servers.

controls.control: Ensure that the configuration of all system components associated with data transmission, storage, and SOC activities is validated against the authorized configuration monthly.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify all system components associated with data transmission, storage, and personalization are validated against the authorized configuration monthly.

controls.control: Ensure all systems used in support of the SOC networks are actively supported in the form of regular updates.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that all systems used in support of the SOC networks are actively supported in the form of regular updates.

controls.control: Evaluate and install the latest security-relevant patches for all system components within 30 days of their release (if they pass validation tests).

testingProcedures.description:
Examine a sample of system components and related software to:

Compare the list of security patches installed on each system component to the most recent vendor security-patch list; and

Verify the applicable vendor-supplied security patches are installed within 30 days of their release.

controls.control:
Verify the integrity and quality of the patches before application,

including source authenticity.

testingProcedures.description: Examine procedures to verify that a process is defined, the source of the patches is authenticated, and that the quality of the patch is validated before installation.
Interview personnel to verify that patch installation process conforms to written procedures.

controls.control: Make a backup of the system being changed before applying any patches. The backup must be securely stored.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of system components and related software and compare the list of security patches installed against backup file entries to verify backups are performed.
Observe security control mechanisms for backups and verify they are in place and active.
Interview personnel and review patch update procedures to verify backups are required before applying patches. Identify controls for secure storage.

controls.control: Implement critical patches to all Internet-facing system components within seven business days of release. When this is not possible the CISO, IT security manager, or IT director must clearly record that they understand that a critical patch is required and authorize its implementation within a maximum of 30 business days.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine a sample of Internet-facing system components and compare the list of security patches installed on each system to the most recent vendor security-patch list, to verify that:

  • Applicable, critical vendor-supplied security patches are installed within 7 days of release. OR

  • Supporting documentation is in place recording that the CISO, IT security manager, and IT director understand and accept the risk and ensure implementation occurs within 30 business days.

Examine policies and procedures related to security-patch installation to verify processes are defined for installation of critical patches to Internet-facing system components within 7 business days of release.

controls.control: Ensure that emergency hardware and software implementations comply with the procedures and validation requirements established for emergency implementations.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the documented procedures for emergency hardware and software implementation.
Examine a sample of emergency and hardware and software changes to verify they follow documented procedures.

controls.control: Ensure that emergency hardware and software implementations follow the configuration and patch management requirements in this section.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of emergency hardware and software implementations to verify that all configuration and patch management procedures are followed.
Interview personnel and review documentation to verify that emergency changes followed stated configuration and patch management requirements.

controls.control: Audit Logs

Ensure that audit logs exist for all networks and network devices in the vendor environment. This includes operating system logs, security software logs, or product logs and application logs containing security events.

testingProcedures.description: Examine all networks and network devices in the vendor environment—including systems and applications connected to the cloud-based provision network—to ensure that audit logs are enabled and function correctly.

Interview personnel to ensure that audit trails are enabled and active for identified items, including operating system logs, security software logs, product logs, and application logs containing security events.

controls.control:
Ensure that audit logs include at least the following components:

  • User identification

  • Event type

  • Valid date and time stamp

  • Success or failure indication

  • Origination of the event Identity or name of the affected data, system component, or resources

  • Access to audit logs

  • Changes in access privileges

testingProcedures.description:
Examine the audit logs to ensure they contain the required components.

  • User identification

  • Event type

  • Valid date and time stamp

  • Success or failure indication

  • Origination of the event

  • Identity or name of the affected data, system component, or resources

  • Access to audit logs

  • Changes in access privileges

controls.control:
Ensure that procedures are documented and followed for audit log review and reporting of unusual activity. Log reviews may be automated or manual and must include authentication, authorization, and directory servers. At a minimum, log review frequency must adhere to the following:

  • Immediate (real time) response to threats designated as alerts for high risk associated events

  • Daily review of IDS and IPS systems

  • Weekly review for wireless access points and authentication servers

  • Monthly review for routers

  • Monthly review of user account audit logs for databases, application, and operating systems.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedures to verify that procedures are defined for reviewing and reporting of unusual activity and include requirements for log frequency as stated in the requirement.
Interview personnel to verify the stated policies and procedures are known and followed.
Examine a sample of each log type and frequency and obtain evidence that log review was performed. Unless specified by the procedures, the order of assessment is at the discretion of the auditor.

controls.control: Verify at least once a month that all systems are meeting log requirements.

testingProcedures.description: Examine evidence that demonstrates monthly verification that systems are meeting the logging requirements.
Interview personnel to ensure they verify at least monthly that systems are meeting the logging requirements.

controls.control: Ensure that logs for all critical systems are backed up daily, secured, and retained for at least one year. Logs must be accessible for at least three months online and one year offline.

testingProcedures.description: For both online and backed-up audit logs, review relevant security controls to ensure access is appropriate.

Examine logs for critical systems to:

  • Verify that logs are securely backed up daily.

  • Verify that logs are accessible online for at least three months.

  • Verify that logs are retained offline for one year.

controls.control: Protect and maintain the integrity of the audit logs from any form of modification.

testingProcedures.description: Examine relevant security controls for both online and backed-up audit logs to ensure the ability to modify or delete audit logs is prohibited.

controls.control: Implement a security-incident and event-logging framework for its organization.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to ensure existence of an incident-response process.
Interview personnel to verify they are aware of their security-incident and event-logging framework.
Examine log entries to verify framework is active and in use.

controls.control: Backup and Recovery for SOC Networks
The backup and recovery procedures for SOC environments must be documented.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify existence of procedures supporting the backup and recovery of the SOC environments must be documented.

controls.control: The procedures must include the backup and recovery of hardware and software that support the SOC activity.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify they include requirements for the backup and recovery of hardware and software that support the SOC activity.

controls.control:
The procedures must differentiate between and address short-term

and long-term service outages.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify they include requirements for both short-term and long-term service outages.

controls.control: The vendor must protect backup copies from intentional or unintentional modifications or destruction.

testingProcedures.description: Examine applicable access-control lists to ensure the ability to modify or delete audit backups is prohibited.

controls.control: Backups must be encrypted and protected equivalent to the primary data as delineated in Section 3.1, “Classifications,” of the PCI CPP Logical Security Standards.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation about the system used to protect backups to ensure that it is protected equivalent to the primary data—e.g., including the vendor, type of system/process, and the encryption algorithms used to encrypt backups.
Interview personnel and review documentation to identify backups and their data classification.
Examine a sample of backups and verify strong cryptography, with associated key-management processes and procedures where used.

controls.control: Controls must be established to prohibit creating unauthorized backups.

testingProcedures.description: Examine existing security controls to verify they prohibit the creation of unauthorized backups.

controls.control: If the recovery procedures include an alternate processing site, the alternate site must be VPA-approved for SOC activities before any SOC activity service may begin at the alternate site.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel and review documentation to identify alternate processing sites.
Examine documentation to verify that the alternate site has been VPA-approved to perform provisioning services before the provisioning occurs.

controls.control: Software Design and Development
General
Document the design, development, and maintenance processes.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation of design, development, and maintenance processes to verify existence.

controls.control: Ensure these activities are based on industry standards and security is an integral part of the software lifecycle process. Web applications must be developed based on secure coding guidelines such as the OWASP Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, and CERT Secure Coding.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine policies and procedures to verify that:

  • The software life cycle process aligns with industry standards; and

  • Web application development is based on recognized secure coding guidelines.

controls.control: Document all software components for each system and describe the functionality provided.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify it covers software components for each system and describes how they function.

controls.control: Protect any software backup copies from accidental destruction.
Design
The vendor must document the flow of SMS data within the environment from the receipt/generation to end of lifecycle.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify documentation includes information to support the receipt/generation of data to the end of the lifecycle.
Examine data-flow diagrams for SMS data within the environment from the receipt/generation to end of lifecycle.

controls.control: Development
Ensure access to source code for applications used on the SOC network is restricted to authorized personnel only.

testingProcedures.description: Examine approval records to ensure access to source code was authorized.
Interview personnel to identify locations of application source code.
Examine system configuration and access-control lists to identify users and processes that have access to source code components.

controls.control: Ensure separation of duties exists between the staff assigned to the development environment and those assigned to the SOC environment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine access-control settings to verify that access controls are in place to enforce separation of personnel assigned to the development/test environments and the SOC environment(s).
Examine policies and procedures to verify a separation of duties between personnel assigned to the development/test environments and those assigned to the SOC environment.

controls.control: Ensure that software source code is restricted to only authorized staff. Staff access of source code must follow a documented process. The authorizations and approvals must be documented.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system configuration and access-control lists to identify users and processes that have access to source code components.
Examine a sample of access request records to verify the access followed the documented process and was authorized.
Examine documented policies and procedures for granting access to source code and verify authorizations and approvals are required.

controls.control: Software implementation
Establish and maintain a documented software release process. Quality assurance must include testing of the code for security issues prior to any software releases.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine documentation to verify a quality assurance process is required as part of the software release

process and testing of code is performed before software is released.
Examine a sample of recent software updates and identify evidence to verify testing of the code was performed.
Interview personnel to verify a software release process exists and is in use.

controls.control: For internally developed software, ensure that security testing includes verification that temporary code, hard-coded keys, and suspicious code are removed.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify it addresses removing temporary code, hard-coded keys, and suspicious code.
Examine a sample of recent internally developed software updates and verify steps to remove temporary code, hard-coded keys, and suspicious code were performed.
Examine policies/procedures to identify testing processes for internally developed software.

controls.control: Ensure all software implementation complies with Section C.6.13, “Change Management.”

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent software updates to verify they comply with Section C.6.13, “Change Management.”

controls.control: Test software prior to implementation to ensure correct operation.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent software updates and verify evidence exists that testing software prior to implementation was performed.

controls.control: All testing must be done on a dedicated test environment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to verify they address prevention of debugging within production environment.
Interview personnel to identify the controls in place to prevent debugging in the production environment.

controls.control: Test and live environments must be segregated.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedures to verify that test and live environments are required to be separated

controls.control: Prevent debugging within SOC environment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedures to verify that debugging is not allowed within the SOC environment.

controls.control: Have a predefined PC device configuration for PC devices used within the SOC environment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedure that specify a pre-defined PC device configuration for PC devices used within the SOC environment.

controls.control: Implement an approval process for all software beyond the standard PC device configuration for PC devices used within the SOC environment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedures to verify that an approval process exists for any PC software installed beyond the standard configuration

controls.control: Ensure no unauthorized software can be installed.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies and procedures to verify that unauthorized software is not allowed to be installed

controls.control: Ensure all software is transferred from development to production in accordance with the change-control process.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of software installs to verify they followed the change-control process.
Examine policies and procedures to verify that all software transferred from development to production is required to follow the change-control process.

controls.control: User Management and System Access Control
User Management
Ensure that procedures are documented and followed by security personnel responsible for granting access to vendor’s networks, applications, and information.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to ensure they address granting access to vendor’s networks, applications, and information.
Interview personnel to identify those authorized to perform and processes followed for granting access to vendor’s network, applications, and information.
Examine a sample of recent access requests to verify they were processed by authorized personnel and in accordance with documented procedures.

controls.control: Restrict approval and level of access to staff with documented business need before access is granted. At a minimum, documented approvals must be retained while the account is active.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine policies/procedures to ensure they address that:

  • Approval and level of access must be restricted to those with a documented business need before access is granted; and

  • Documented approvals of access in place must be retained while the account is active.

controls.control: Restrict systems access by unique user ID to only those individuals who have a business need.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of user accounts to verify each individual associated with a unique user ID has a documented, valid business need for the system access.

controls.control: Only grant individuals the minimum level of access sufficient to perform their duties.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent access requests to verify user access is limited to least privilege and based on documented business need.
Interview security administration personnel to verify access is granted based on least-privilege principles sufficient to perform their duties.
Examine policies/procedures to verify they require that access be granted based on least-privilege principles sufficient to perform their duties.

controls.control: Make certain that systems authentication requires at least the use of a unique ID and password.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system authentication settings and verify that user IDs in the system are unique and in order to gain access, a password is required.
Examine policies/procedures for system access to verify they require at least the use of a unique ID and password.

controls.control: Restrict administrative access to the minimum number of individuals required for management of the system.

testingProcedures.description: Interview management to understand the minimum number of administrative user resources required to support the personalization environment.
Examine user ID lists and security privileges to identify users with administrative access and verify the number of users with administrative access aligns with management’s expectations.

controls.control: Ensure that group, shared, and generic accounts and passwords are disabled wherever the system supports unique values.

testingProcedures.description: Examine polices/procedures to verify they require that group, shared, and generic accounts and passwords are disabled wherever the system supports unique values.
Examine a sample of system components and user ID lists to verify group, shared, and generic accounts and passwords are disabled.

controls.control: Ensure that where generic administrative accounts cannot be disabled, these accounts are used only when unique administrator sign-on credentials are not possible and only in an emergency.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures for the management of generic administrative accounts that cannot be disabled. Verify these accounts are used only when unique administrator sign-on credentials are not possible and only in an emergency.

Examine system security event log to identify when applicable generic administrative accounts were used and verify there is supporting documentation that authorizes their use in an emergency.

controls.control: Ensure that when generic administrative accounts are used, the password is managed under dual control where no individual has access to the full password. Each component of the password must comply with the password control requirements in Section C.6.2, “Password Control.”

testingProcedures.description: Interview system administration personnel to verify password-management practices require that generic administrative passwords are managed under dual control and in accordance with Section 6.2

Examine policies/procedures for the management of generic administrative account passwords and verify procedures require that such passwords be managed under dual control and in accordance with Section C.6.2, “Password Control.”

controls.control: Validate all system access at least quarterly.

testingProcedures.description: Examine validation evidence to verify the activity is performed.
Interview personnel to verify system access is re-validated at least quarterly.

controls.control: Revalidate employee access to any systems upon a change of duties.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of HR transfer records and verify that revalidation was performed.
Interview personnel to verify any staff access is revalidated when there is a change in duties.

controls.control: Ensure that access controls enforce segregation of duties.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify that policies/procedures support segregation of duties. See glossary definition, “Segregation of Duties,” in the Security Requirements.

controls.control: Strictly limit privileged or administrative access and ensure such access is approved by both the user’s manager and the IT security manager.

testingProcedures.description: Examine access-control settings to ensure access confirms to stated policies.
Examine a sample of administrative-access requests and verify access was approved by the user’s manager and IT Security Manager.
Interview personnel to identify controls that limit privileged or administrative access.

controls.control: Establish management oversight of privileged access to ensure compliance with segregation of duties.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify controls that provide oversight of privileged access and compliance with segregation of duties policies.
Examine evidence—e.g., audit logs—to verify management oversight is performed.
Examine policies/procedures to verify they require oversight of privileged access that ensures compliance with segregation of duties.

controls.control: Ensure that all privileged administrative access is logged and reviewed weekly.

testingProcedures.description: Examine evidence—e.g., access logs—to verify reviews are performed according to policies and procedures.
Examine policies/procedures to verify that they require weekly review of privileged administrative access.

controls.control: Password Control
General
Implement a policy and detailed procedures relating to the generation, use, renewal, and distribution of passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policy and detailed procedures to identify processes for generation, use, renewal, and distribution of passwords.

controls.control: Implement procedures for handling lost, forgotten, and compromised passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policy and detailed procedures to identify processes for handling lost, forgotten, and compromised passwords.
Interview system administrators to validate adherence to procedures.

controls.control: Distribute password procedures and policies to all users who have access to any information or system used as part of the SOC process.

testingProcedures.description: Interview a sample of user population to verify password procedures and policies were distributed.
Examine procedures for disseminating password procedures and policies to users with access to cardholder data or any system used as part of the personalization process.

controls.control: Ensure that only users with administrative privileges can administer other users’ passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a sample of user password resets and verify only users with administrative privileges can perform a reset.
Examine procedures for managing user IDs and verify that only users with administrative privileges can administer user passwords.

controls.control: Not store passwords in clear text.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of system components and their password files to verify that passwords are unreadable during storage. Change all default passwords.
Examine system documentation and configuration settings to verify that passwords are not stored in clear text.

controls.control: Change all default passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of system components and attempts to log on (with system administrator help) to the devices and applications using default vendor-supplied accounts and passwords, to verify that ALL default passwords have been changed. (Use vendor manuals and sources on the Internet to find vendor-supplied accounts/passwords.)

controls.control: Characteristics and Usage
Systems are configured so that newly issued and reset passwords are set to a unique value for each user.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of system configuration settings to verify newly issued and reset passwords are set to a unique value for each user.
Interview personnel to verify newly issued and reset passwords are set to a unique value for each user.

controls.control: Newly issued passwords are changed on first use.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system configuration settings to verify newly issued passwords are changed on first use.

controls.control: “First use” passwords expire if not used within 24 hours of distribution.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system configuration settings to verify that first-time passwords are set to expire if not used within 24 hours.

controls.control: Systems enforce password lengths of at least 12 characters.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that password parameters are set to require a minimum length of at least 12 characters.

controls.control:
Passwords consist of a combination of at least three of the following:

  • Upper-case letters

  • Lower-case letters

  • Numbers

  • Special characters

testingProcedures.description:
Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that user passwords are set to require at least the following strength/complexity:

controls.description:
Note: Information based on Uptime Institute definitions for “Concurrently Maintainable Site Infrastructure”

The SOC infrastructure must meet specific requirements to ensure an adequate level of continued service is maintained. The following points are the minimum of what is needed to provide to stable service:

controls.control: Each SOC supplied with at least two independent internet connections to provide suitable fail-over. This enables all local sites serviced by the SOC to maintain connectivity with the SOC.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify the existence of at least two independent internet connections to provide suitable fail-over.

controls.control: Each SOC location must have auxiliary power or battery backup system to ensure all associated equipment used by the SOC is fully supported at all times.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that recovery point objectives are defined as part of SLAs to ensure minimal data loss at SOC.

controls.control: Performance Testing

  • Hardware performance to ensure appropriate levels of redundancy which minimizes impacts of SOC and/or the defined managed vendor facility operations for potential outages.

Examine documents for the design of the vault to verify that it is constructed of reinforced concrete or at least meets the Underwriters Laboratories Class I Burglary Certification Standard—e.g., UL 608 or EN1143-1 class 6).

controls.control: An outside wall of the building must not be used as a wall of the vault.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that an outside wall of the building is not used as a wall of the vault.

controls.control: If the construction of the vault leaves a small (dead) space between the vault and the outside wall, this space must be constantly monitored for intrusion—e.g., via motion sensors.

testingProcedures.description: Examine evidence to verify that any small (dead) space between the vault and the outside wall is constantly monitored for intrusion.
Observe to verify that if the construction of the vault leaves a small (dead) space between the vault and the outside wall, the space is constantly monitored for intrusion—e.g., via motion sensors.

controls.control: No windows are permitted.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that no windows are in the vault.

controls.control: There must be no access to the vault except through the vault doors and gate configurations meeting these requirements. The vault must be protected with a sufficient number of intruder-detection devices that provide an early attack indication—e.g., seismic, vibration/shock, microphonic wire, microphone, etc.—on attempts to enter and also provide full coverage of the walls, ceiling, and floor.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe access to the vault to verify the following exist to protect access to the vault:

The vault has a sufficient number of intruder-detection devices that provide early attack indication—e.g., seismic, vibration/shock, microphonic wire, microphone, etc.—for any attempts to enter as well as full coverage of the walls, ceiling, and floor; and

Access to the vault is only through vault doors and gates configured with intruder-detection devices.

controls.control: The vault must be fitted with a main steel-reinforced door with a dual- locking mechanism (mechanical and/or logical—e.g., mechanical combination and biometrics) that requires physical and simultaneous dual-control access. The access mechanism requires that access occurs under dual control and does not allow entry by a single individual—i.e., it is not feasible for a single individual to use credentials belonging to someone else to simulate dual access.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe to verify the protection of the vault includes but is not limited to:

  • Vault is fitted with a main steel-reinforced door with a dual-locking mechanism (mechanical and/or logical—e.g., mechanical combination and biometrics) that requires physical and simultaneous dual-control access.

  • Vault has access mechanism that requires access under dual control and does not allow entry by a single individual—i.e., it is not feasible for a single individual to use credentials belonging to someone else to simulate dual access.

controls.control: Opening of the main vault door must always be under dual control requiring two authorized staff to be simultaneously present and involved in the opening and closing of the door.

testingProcedures.description: Observe the opening and closing of the main vault door to verify it is under dual control.
Examine procedures to verify opening and closing of the main vault door is always under dual control.
Examine procedures to verify opening and closing of the main vault door is always under dual control.

controls.control: If the vault door is required to remain open during production hours, an inner grille must be used. The vault door or inner grille must remain closed and locked at all times, except when staff require access to the vault for example to store or remove items. The inner grille must meet the same access-control criteria as other rooms within the HSA.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe (if the vault door is required to remain open during production hours) to verify:

  • An inner grille is used

  • The inner grille remains closed and locked at all times, except when staff require access to the vault—for example, to store or remove items.

  • The inner grille meets the same access-control criteria as other rooms within the HSA.

controls.control: The vault door or the inner grille must be equipped with an automatic closing device and must automatically activate a simultaneous sound alarm, locally and in the security control room, if opened for more than 60 seconds.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe that the vault door or the inner grille are equipped with:

  • An automatic closing device

  • An automatically activated simultaneous sound alarm that will be heard locally and in the security control room, if opened for more than 60 seconds.
Observe sample documents—e.g., logs—to verify the existing controls are in place.

controls.control: Emergency exit doors from the vault to the HSA must meet the strength requirements for a vault door, must be alarmed and not capable of being opened from outside, and must conform to the requirements for emergency exits.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine documentation to verify emergency exit doors from the vault to the HSA:

  • Meet the strength requirements for a vault door.

  • Have alarms.

  • Are not capable of being opened from outside.
Observe to verify emergency exit doors meet the requirements in place.

controls.control: Card components being taken in or out must be recorded in a vault log and confirmed by at least two card production staff.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation—e.g., a sample of logs—to verify card components taken in or out of the vault are recorded in a vault log and confirmed by at least two card production staff.
Interview personnel to verify procedures are followed.

controls.control: Maintenance of these audit control logs is mandatory as defined in Section 3.7.2, “Vault Audit Controls.” These logs must be retained for the longer of five years or the oldest card in the vault.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of the logs to verify that they are retained for the longer of five years or the oldest card in the vault.

controls.control: If the vault also is used to store non-payment products, it must be physically segregated—e.g., stored on dedicated aisles or shelves—to create a physical separation between payment products and other card types.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that if the vault is used to store non-payment products, these non-payment products are physically segregated to create a physical separation between payment products and other card types.

controls.control: All boxes with payment cards must have a label, visibly attached, describing the product type, a unique product identifier number, the quantity of cards contained in the box and the date of control.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe boxes with payment cards to verify they have a label visibly attached, detailing:

  • The product type,

  • A unique product identifier number,

  • The quantity of cards contained in the box, and

  • The date of control.

controls.control: Unsealed boxes are only permitted for stock that requires multiple pulls per day. Unsealed boxes must be in a centralized area within the vault. The counting process must be applied during the pull process, and an inventory count under dual control must be performed for each unsealed box at the end of each shift. All other boxes must be sealed.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe a sample of unsealed boxes to verify:

  • Unsealed boxes are only permitted for stock that requires multiple pulls per day.

  • Unsealed boxes must be in a centralized area within the vault.

  • Counting processes are applied during the pull process.

  • Inventory counts under dual control are performed for each unsealed box at the end of each shift.

  • All other boxes are sealed.

controls.control: Vault storage must be organized so that it is possible to identify the location of any stock item within the vault.

testingProcedures.description: Observe the vault storage to verify that it is organized to be able to identify the location of any stock item within the vault.

controls.control: CCTV surveillance is mandatory and must cover the entire area, ensuring that there are no blind spots.

testingProcedures.description: Observe the vault to identify whether blind spots exist that are not covered.
Examine a sample of CCTV surveillance media to verify coverage is the entire vault area is covered including that there are no blind spots.

controls.control: Separate rooms within the HSA must meet all of the HSA requirements with the exception of person-by-person access.

testingProcedures.description: Observe that separate rooms within the HSA meet the HSA requirements with the exception of person-by-person access.
Examine HSA documentation to verify separate rooms within the HSA meet all of the HSA requirements with the exception of person-by-person access.

controls.control: Toilet rooms are prohibited except where required by local law. Where used, the entry/exit way must be camera-monitored.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that toilets, if present, are required by local law.
Observe to determine that, if present, the toilet room’s entry/exit ways are camera-monitored.

controls.control: If the HSA contains fire doors and these doors are normally closed or can be manually closed, then these doors are subject to the same access controls as any other door that provides access to a room.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that any fire doors present in the HSA are normally closed or can be manually closed, and these doors are subject to the same access controls as any other door that provides access to a room.

controls.control: If the HSA contains fire doors and these doors are locked open and only closed automatically when a fire alarm is activated, then the access controls that normally apply for accessing a room do not apply.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that any fire doors present in the HSA that are locked open and only closed automatically when a fire alarm is activated, do not require the access controls that normally apply for accessing a room.

controls.control: Other Areas
Goods-tools Traps
controls.description: Goods-tools trap configuration options are as follows:

controls.control:
One-room configuration:

  • The goods-tools trap is composed of a unique, closed, solid construction room (goods transfer room) and two doors (inner and external) minimizing the physical contact between the individuals collecting or delivering materials and the HSA staff.

  • In this configuration, the goods-tools trap must be operated as follows:

  • The movement detector is deactivated when someone swipes the access card in the card reader.

  • The person opens the door, introduces the package, and closes the door.

  • The movement detector is reactivated automatically, so any person inside the goods-tools trap is detected. If someone is detected, the cycle cannot be completed, and the other goods-tools trap door cannot be opened to take the package back.

  • If no motion is detected in the trap, and the first door has been closed, the second door in the HSA can be opened for someone to take the package.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe good tools trap configuration:

  • If a one room configuration is used, perform test procedures for Requirement a).

  • If a two-room configuration is used, perform the test procedures for Requirement b) below.

Observe the room configuration to verify the goods-tools trap one-room is configured and operated as follows:

  • Composed of a unique, closed, solid construction room (goods transfer room) and two doors (inner and external), minimizing the physical contact between the individuals collecting or delivering materials and the HSA staff.

  • Movement detector is deactivated when someone swipes the access card in the card reader.

  • The person opens the door, introduces the package, and closes the door.

  • Movement detector is reactivated automatically, so any person inside the goods-tools trap is detected.

  • If someone is detected, the cycle cannot be completed, and the other goods-tools trap door cannot be opened to take the package back.

  • If no motion is detected in the trap, and the first door has been closed, the second door in the HSA can be opened for someone to take the package.

controls.control:
Two-room configuration:

  • In this configuration, the goods-tools trap is composed of two consecutive rooms, similar to the classical shipping and delivery room configuration.

  • Security requirements, protection devices, and access procedures are the same as for the standard shipping and delivering area configuration, as defined below.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe to verify it is configured and operated as follows:

  • Goods-tools trap is composed of two consecutive rooms, similar to the classical shipping and delivery room configuration.

  • Security requirements, protection devices, and access procedures are the same as for the standard shipping and delivering area configuration, as defined below.

controls.control: Shipping and Delivery Areas

To facilitate the shipment and delivery of card components, the loading/unloading area must be composed of at least two consecutive enclosed rooms and three doors (external, intermediate, and inner), which minimizes physical contact between the individuals collecting or delivering materials and the shipment/delivery card production staff.
controls.description: Note: If existing facilities have used wired enclosures for the outer room, they may continue. All new facilities requiring initial validation against these requirements must comply with the requirement as written⎯i.e., a room that is part of the building structure.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe to verify the shipping and delivery areas (loading/unloading) of card components to have at a minimum:

  • At least two consecutive enclosed rooms and three doors (external, intermediate, and inner), and

  • Minimization of physical contact between the individuals collecting or delivering materials and the shipment/delivery card production staff.

controls.control: All shipping and delivery doors must operate on an electronic and interlocking basis so that when one of the doors is open the others are electronically locked.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a demonstration of the shipping and delivery processes to verify the shipping and delivery doors operate on an electronic and interlocking basis so that when one of the doors is open the others are electronically locked. Test in multiple configurations with different doors starting in the open position. With all doors closed, try opening multiple doors at the same time—i.e., badging and/or pressing open buttons together for different doors.

controls.control: An intercom communications system must be contained in this area to allow identification of incoming drivers.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that an intercom communications system is operational in this area to allow identification of incoming drivers.

controls.control: One of the rooms in the shipping area must contain a solution to allow the exchange of control documents without coming into contact with external personnel, as well as being able to communicate with and visually identify them—e.g., a security window, video intercom, CCTV monitors, etc.

testingProcedures.description:
Observe to verify that one of the rooms in the shipping area:

  • Contains a solution to allow the exchange of control documents without coming into contact with external personnel; and

  • Allows communication with and visual identification of external personnel.

controls.control: The inner shipping/delivery area door must have access control installed to restrict access to authorized users and to record usage. The logging at a minimum must include each opening and closing of the door.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of logs to verify the shipping/delivery area doors have access controls installed to restrict access to authorized users and that these records log each opening and closing of the doors, at a minimum.
Examine to verify the inner shipping/delivery area door to verify it has access control installed to restrict access to authorized users and to record usage are in place.

controls.control: The guards may operate the external door of the outer room area only after the driver is identified and the production staff is informed about the ongoing shipment or delivery operation. To prevent unauthorized access to the HSAs through the shipping and delivery rooms, the inner room must be protected by an internal movement detector that prevents the opening of the internal door and the intermediate door of the inner room if movement is detected inside this inner room.

testingProcedures.description: Example a sample of logs to identify activity times and the associated CCTV recordings to verify the guards operate the external door of the outer room area only after the driver has been identified and the production staff is informed about the ongoing shipment or delivery operation.

Examine policy and procedures to verify access-control mechanisms exist to support the prevention of unauthorized access to the HSAs to include that the inner room is protected by an internal movement detector that prevents the opening of the internal door and the intermediate door of the inner room if movement is detected inside this inner room.
Interview a sample of guards and other personnel to verify that procedures are followed.

controls.control: An alarm must be generated automatically and logged in the central alarm system, and all shipment and delivery area doors must be blocked each time movement is detected by the movement detector located inside the inner room when the intermediate and inner doors are both closed and locked.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policy and procedures to verify the shipment and delivery area doors are blocked each time movement is detected by the movement detectors located inside the inner room when the intermediate and inner doors are both closed and locked.

Examine a sample of logs to verify an alarm was generated automatically and logged in the central alarm system, and that all shipment and delivery area doors were blocked each time movement is detected by the movement detector located inside the inner room when the intermediate and inner doors are both closed and locked.

Examine policy and procedures to verify the central alarm system generates an alarm when movement is detected by the movement detectors located inside the inner room when the intermediate and inner doors are both closed and locked.

controls.control: To liberate a person detected inside the room and stop the alarm, the software monitoring the access-control system must only allow the opening of the last activated door. Either a logical (software) or physical (alarm report book) log of the event must be kept for at least two years.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the procedures to verify a process is in place to release a person found inside the room and that the software monitoring the access-control system allows the opening of only the last activated door.
Examine either a logical (software) or a physical (alarm report book) log of such events to validate a record is kept for at least two years.

controls.control: The vendor must install CCTV cameras and orient the cameras to cover the external and inner access doors to the shipping and delivery areas and capture all activities during shipping and delivery operations.

testingProcedures.description: Observe the CCTV camera locations to verify the CCTV cameras cover the external and inner access doors to the shipping and delivery areas and capture all activities during shipping and delivery operations.

Observe displayed or recorded images to verify the CCTV cameras cover the external and inner access doors to the shipping and delivery areas and capture all activities during shipping and delivery operations.

controls.control:
The vendor must install at least:

  • One external CCTV camera covering the external shipping and delivery area door and its environment

  • Two CCTV cameras inside the outer room covering all sides of the vehicle

  • One CCTV camera inside the inner room covering the shipping and delivery operations

testingProcedures.description:
Observe to verify the CCTV cameras from the security control room have been installed to cover at a minimum:

  • One external CCTV camera covering the external shipping and delivery area door and its environment

  • Two CCTV cameras inside the outer room covering all sides of the vehicle

  • One CCTV camera inside the inner room covering the shipping and delivery operations

controls.control: The images captured and recorded by these CCTV cameras must be displayed on the security control room monitors in real time, allowing the guards to control the shipping and delivery operations.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that the images for the cameras noted in the prior section are displayed on the security control room monitors in real time.

controls.control: These images must also be displayed on a monitor located beside the security window, allowing the production staff to oversee the shipping and delivery operations.

testingProcedures.description: Observe the monitor located beside the security window to verify the images are displayed on that monitor visible to the production staff overseeing the shipping and delivery operations.

controls.control: Internal Security
Alarm Systems

To alert personnel working in the vicinity of and in the security control room, local alarms or flashing lights must activate when a door or gate to a restricted area is left open for more than 30 seconds except where otherwise specified in this document.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a sample demonstration to verify that local alarms or flashing lights are activated when a door or gate to a restricted area is left open for more than 30 seconds except where otherwise specified in the security requirements.

controls.control: The alarm system must be protected by an auxiliary power or battery backup system with capabilities for ensuring operation for a minimum of 48 hours in the event of a power failure.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify the alarm system is protected by an auxiliary power or battery backup system with capabilities for ensuring operation for a minimum of 48 hours in the event of a power failure.
Observe the presence of an auxiliary power or battery backup system to verify the alarm system is protected with backup power in the event of a power failure.

controls.control: The system must notify the vendor in real time in the event the backup system is invoked.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of documents—e.g., logs or alarm testing—to verify the system notified the vendor in real time when backup systems were invoked.
Interview the physical security manager to determine the method and technology used to notify the vendor in real time in the event back-up systems are invoked.
Examine documentation to verify a process is in place for the backup system to notify the vendor in real time in the event the backup system is invoked.

controls.control: The alarm activation and deactivation must be checked and confirmed by an electronic device, guards, private security company, or local police force to ensure that the pre-arranged alarm time settings have been respected. The alarm deactivation process must allow for the generation of a fast, silent alarm in case of threat.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify the alarm deactivation process allows for the generation of a fast, silent alarm in case of threat.

Examine alarm policy and procedures to verify at a minimum:

  • The alarm activation and deactivation are checked and confirmed by an electronic device, guards, private security company, or local police force to ensure that the pre-arranged alarm time settings have been respected.

  • The alarm deactivation process allows for the generation of a fast, silent alarm in case of threat.

Examine a sample of logs to verify the alarm activation and deactivation is checked and confirmed by an electronic device, guards, private security company, or local police force to ensure that the pre- arranged alarm time settings have been respected.

controls.control: A specific procedure must be established to ensure quick corrective action in case an alarm is not activated in accordance with pre-arranged alarm time settings.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify they are knowledgeable of and able to execute the procedure.
Examine documentation to verify that a specific procedure has been established to ensure quick corrective action in case an alarm is not activated in accordance with pre-arranged alarm time settings.

controls.control: Alarm activation and deactivation codes must be known only by guards or security team members authorized to use them.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify alarm activation and deactivation codes are known only by the card production staff authorized to use them.
Interview personnel to verify alarm activation and deactivation codes are known only by the guards or security team members authorized to use them.

controls.control: Codes must be deactivated upon termination of any guards or security team members with knowledge of the code.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify alarm activation and deactivation codes are deactivated upon termination of any staff with knowledge of the code.
Examine documentation to verify alarm activation and deactivation codes are deactivated upon termination of any staff with knowledge of the code.

controls.control: Guards and card production staff must follow these procedures in case of alarm system activation. These procedures must be clearly described and included in the internal security procedures manual.

testingProcedures.description: Interview guards and card production staff to verify they know the procedures in case of an alarm system activation.
Examine the internal security procedures manual to verify that it states guards and card production staff must follow described procedures in case of alarm system activation.
Examine a sample of training materials to verify guards and card production staff know the procedures in case of an alarm system activation.

controls.control: Access contacts and motion detectors must be activated in zones where no staff are present—e.g., vault, storage, production areas, shipping and delivery areas.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a demonstration of someone badging in and badging out, but not actually egressing the restricted area to verify the detection works.
Examine a sample of logs to verify access contacts and motion detectors are activated in zones where no staff are present—e.g., vault, storage, production areas, shipping and delivery areas.
Examine documents to verify access contacts and motion detectors are to be activated in zones where no staff are present—e.g., vault, storage, production areas, shipping and delivery areas.

controls.control: Access-Control System Administration
Identification Badges
Procedures must be documented and followed for managing identification (ID) badges.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of logs to verify procedures are followed in managing ID badges.
Examine badging administration documentation to verify procedures are defined for managing ID badges.

controls.control: The vendor must issue a photo identification (ID) badge to each card production staff member and consultant. A temporary badge valid ONLY for the work shift does not need to contain a picture.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of logs to verify badge issuance to card production staff and consultants.
Examine documented procedures to verify the vendor issues a photo identification badge to each card production staff member and consultant.

controls.control: ID badges and lanyards must not be imprinted with the company name or logo and are not allowed to be imprinted with any information that may identify the vendor’s name or location.

testingProcedures.description: Observe to verify that ID badges and lanyards do not contain the corporate name or logo or any information that may identify the vendor’s name or location.

controls.control: Access credentials (which may be the ID badge) must be programmed only for the access required based on job function.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify access is required based on job function.
Examine to verify a sample of access credentials (which may be the ID badge) are programmed only for the access required based on job function.
Examine access-control procedures to verify that the access credentials (which may be the ID badge) are programmed only for the access required based on job function.

controls.control: ID Badge or Access Card Usage

The access-control system must grant physical access to card production staff or consultants only during authorized working hours, and only to those areas required by the card production staff or consultants’ job functions.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a demonstration of one or more individuals attempting to access areas they are not authorized for to verify the access-control system prevents that access.
Examine a sample of logs to verify that the physical access is only granted during authorized working hours and only to the areas required by the individual’s job functions.

Examine access-control system settings to verify physical access to card production staff or consultants is only during authorized working hours, and only to those areas required by the card production staff or consultants’ job functions.

controls.control: Personnel must display their ID badges at all times while in the facility.

testingProcedures.description: Observe that personnel display their ID badges at all times while in the facility.

controls.control: Card production staff and consultants are responsible for their ID and access badges and must report any lost/stolen or broken badges to the physical security manager immediately.

testingProcedures.description: Examine sample reports to verify lost/stolen or broken badges have been reported to the security manager.
Interview personnel to verify they have knowledge to report any lost/stolen or broken badges to the physical security manager immediately.

Examine documentation to verify policies and procedures address but are not limited to:

  • Card production staff and consultants are responsible for securing their ID badge from loss or theft.

  • If an individual determines his/her ID badge has been lost or misplaced, they must notify the physical security manager immediately.

controls.control: The audit logs of the ID badge access-control system changes and exception conditions must be reviewed weekly to ensure badge assignments are appropriate and the system is functioning appropriately.

testingProcedures.description: Examine logs to verify that the audit logs of the ID badge access-control system changes and exception conditions are reviewed weekly to ensure badge assignments are appropriate and the system is functioning appropriately.

controls.control: ID Badge or Access Card Inventory and Management
controls.description: The physical security manager is responsible for unassigned ID badges and must:

controls.control: Maintain an inventory of unassigned ID badges.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the unassigned badge inventory log to verify completeness.

controls.control: Ensure dual control exists for badge access and distribution to individuals.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of logs to verify dual control for badge access and assignments.
Examine procedures to validate a process is in place to have dual control for badge access and distribution to individuals.

controls.control: Ensure ID badges are retrieved from terminated individuals prior to their departure from the facility.

testingProcedures.description: Examine procedures to validate a process is in place to retrieve ID badges from terminated individuals prior to their departure from the facility.
Examine a sample of terminated personnel documentation to verify ID badges were retrieved from each terminated individual prior to their departure from the facility.

controls.control: Ensure all access rights are immediately deactivated.

testingProcedures.description: Examine procedures to validate a process is in place to deactivate all access rights immediately on a departure of an individual.
Examine a sample of terminated personnel documentation to verify all access rights were immediately deactivated.

controls.control: Maintain precise documentation accounting for all lost badges.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of terminated personnel documentation to verify all access rights were immediately deactivated.
Examine a sample of documentation to verify existence of an audit trail of all lost badges.

controls.control: Access-Control System
Activity Reports
All procedures for access control must be documented and kept current.

testingProcedures.description: Interview the access-control system administrator to validate access documents are current.
Examine documentation to verify access-control procedures exist and are current.

controls.control:
The access-control system must log sufficient information to produce the daily card activity reports detailed below:

  • Card reader

  • Card reader status

  • Card identification

  • Date and time of access

  • Access attempts results

  • Unauthorized attempts

  • Anti-pass-back violation and corrective actions taken

  • Access-control system changes describing:

    • The reasons for the change, and

    • The person who made the change.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine a sample of access-control system logs to verify they contain the following information at a minimum:

  • Card reader

  • Card reader status

  • Card identification

  • Date and time of access

  • Access attempts results

  • Unauthorized attempts

  • Anti-pass-back violation and corrective actions taken

  • Access-control system changes describing:

    • The date and time of the change,

    • The reasons for the change, and
